1 | Mathematics and Physics Have the Same Foundations

One of the many surprising (and to me, unexpected) implications of our Physics Project is its suggestion of a very deep correspondence between the foundations of physics and mathematics. We might have imagined that physics would have certain laws, and mathematics would have certain theories, and that while they might be historically related, there wouldn‚Äôt be any fundamental formal correspondence between them.

But what our Physics Project suggests is that underneath everything we physically experience there is a single very general abstract structure‚Äîthat we call the ruliad‚Äîand that our physical laws arise in an inexorable way from the particular samples we take of this structure. We can think of the ruliad as the entangled limit of all possible computations‚Äîor in effect a representation of all possible formal processes. And this then leads us to the idea that perhaps the ruliad might underlie not only physics but also mathematics‚Äîand that everything in mathematics, like everything in physics, might just be the result of sampling the ruliad.

Of course, mathematics as it‚Äôs normally practiced doesn‚Äôt look the same as physics. But the idea is that they can both be seen as views of the same underlying structure. What makes them different is that physical and mathematical observers sample this structure in somewhat different ways. But since in the end both kinds of observers are associated with human experience they inevitably have certain core characteristics in common. And the result is that there should be ‚Äúfundamental laws of mathematics‚Äù that in some sense mirror the perceived laws of physics that we derive from our physical observation of the ruliad.

So what might those fundamental laws of mathematics be like? And how might they inform our conception of the foundations of mathematics, and our view of what mathematics really is?

The most obvious manifestation of the mathematics that we humans have developed over the course of many centuries is the few million mathematical theorems that have been published in the literature of mathematics. But what can be said in generality about this thing we call mathematics? Is there some notion of what mathematics is like ‚Äúin bulk‚Äù? And what might we be able to say, for example, about the structure of mathematics in the limit of infinite future development?

When we do physics, the traditional approach has been to start from our basic sensory experience of the physical world, and of concepts like space, time and motion‚Äîand then to try to formalize our descriptions of these things, and build on these formalizations. And in its early development‚Äîfor example by Euclid‚Äîmathematics took the same basic approach. But beginning a little more than a century ago there emerged the idea that one could build mathematics purely from formal axioms, without necessarily any reference to what is accessible to sensory experience.

And in a way our Physics Project begins from a similar place. Because at the outset it just considers purely abstract structures and abstract rules‚Äîtypically described in terms of hypergraph rewriting‚Äîand then tries to deduce their consequences. Many of these consequences are incredibly complicated, and full of computational irreducibility. But the remarkable discovery is that when sampled by observers with certain general characteristics that make them like us, the behavior that emerges must generically have regularities that we can recognize, and in fact must follow exactly known core laws of physics.

And already this begins to suggest a new perspective to apply to the foundations of mathematics. But there‚Äôs another piece, and that‚Äôs the idea of the ruliad. We might have supposed that our universe is based on some particular chosen underlying rule, like an axiom system we might choose in mathematics. But the concept of the ruliad is in effect to represent the entangled result of ‚Äúrunning all possible rules‚Äù. And the key point is then that it turns out that an ‚Äúobserver like us‚Äù sampling the ruliad must perceive behavior that corresponds to known laws of physics. In other words, without ‚Äúmaking any choice‚Äù it’s inevitable‚Äîgiven what we‚Äôre like as observers‚Äîthat our ‚Äúexperience of the ruliad‚Äù will show fundamental laws of physics.

But now we can make a bridge to mathematics. Because in embodying all possible computational processes the ruliad also necessarily embodies the consequences of all possible axiom systems. As humans doing physics we‚Äôre effectively taking a certain sampling of the ruliad. And we realize that as humans doing mathematics we‚Äôre also doing essentially the same kind of thing.

But will we see ‚Äúgeneral laws of mathematics‚Äù in the same kind of way that we see ‚Äúgeneral laws of physics‚Äù? It depends on what we‚Äôre like as ‚Äúmathematical observers‚Äù. In physics, there turn out to be general laws‚Äîand concepts like space and motion‚Äîthat we humans can assimilate. And in the abstract it might not be that anything similar would be true in mathematics. But it seems as if the thing mathematicians typically call mathematics is something for which it is‚Äîand where (usually in the end leveraging our experience of physics) it‚Äôs possible to successfully carve out a sampling of the ruliad that‚Äôs again one we humans can assimilate.

When we think about physics we have the idea that there‚Äôs an actual physical reality that exists‚Äîand that we experience physics within this. But in the formal axiomatic view of mathematics, things are different. There‚Äôs no obvious ‚Äúunderlying reality‚Äù there; instead there‚Äôs just a certain choice we make of axiom system. But now, with the concept of the ruliad, the story is different. Because now we have the idea that ‚Äúdeep underneath‚Äù both physics and mathematics there‚Äôs the same thing: the ruliad. And that means that insofar as physics is ‚Äúgrounded in reality‚Äù, so also must mathematics be.

When most working mathematicians do mathematics it seems to be typical for them to reason as if the constructs they‚Äôre dealing with (whether they be numbers or sets or whatever) are ‚Äúreal things‚Äù. But usually there‚Äôs a concept that in principle one could ‚Äúdrill down‚Äù and formalize everything in terms of some axiom system. And indeed if one wants to get a global view of mathematics and its structure as it is today, it seems as if the best approach is to work from the formalization that‚Äôs been done with axiom systems.

In starting from the ruliad and the ideas of our Physics Project we‚Äôre in effect positing a certain ‚Äútheory of mathematics‚Äù. And to validate this theory we need to study the ‚Äúphenomena of mathematics‚Äù. And, yes, we could do this in effect by directly ‚Äúreading the whole literature of mathematics‚Äù. But it‚Äôs more efficient to start from what‚Äôs in a sense the ‚Äúcurrent prevailing underlying theory of mathematics‚Äù and to begin by building on the methods of formalized mathematics and axiom systems.

Over the past century a certain amount of metamathematics has been done by looking at the general properties of these methods. But most often when the methods are systematically used today, it‚Äôs to set up some particular mathematical derivation, normally with the aid of a computer. But here what we want to do is think about what happens if the methods are used ‚Äúin bulk‚Äù. Underneath there may be all sorts of specific detailed formal derivations being done. But somehow what emerges from this is something higher level, something ‚Äúmore human‚Äù‚Äîand ultimately something that corresponds to our experience of pure mathematics.

How might this work? We can get an idea from an analogy in physics. Imagine we have a gas. Underneath, it consists of zillions of molecules bouncing around in detailed and complicated patterns. But most of our ‚Äúhuman‚Äù experience of the gas is at a much more coarse-grained level‚Äîwhere we perceive not the detailed motions of individual molecules, but instead continuum fluid mechanics.

And so it is, I think, with mathematics. All those detailed formal derivations‚Äîfor example of the kind automated theorem proving might do‚Äîare like molecular dynamics. But most of our ‚Äúhuman experience of mathematics‚Äù‚Äîwhere we talk about concepts like integers or morphisms‚Äîis like fluid dynamics. The molecular dynamics is what builds up the fluid, but for most questions of ‚Äúhuman interest‚Äù it‚Äôs possible to ‚Äúreason at the fluid dynamics level‚Äù, without dropping down to molecular dynamics.

It‚Äôs certainly not obvious that this would be possible. It could be that one might start off describing things at a ‚Äúfluid dynamics‚Äù level‚Äîsay in the case of an actual fluid talking about the motion of vortices‚Äîbut that everything would quickly get ‚Äúshredded‚Äù, and that there‚Äôd soon be nothing like a vortex to be seen, only elaborate patterns of detailed microscopic molecular motions. And similarly in mathematics one might imagine that one would be able to prove theorems in terms of things like real numbers but actually find that everything gets ‚Äúshredded‚Äù to the point where one has to start talking about elaborate issues of mathematical logic and different possible axiomatic foundations.

But in physics we effectively have the Second Law of thermodynamics‚Äîwhich we now understand in terms of computational irreducibility‚Äîthat tells us that there‚Äôs a robust sense in which the microscopic details are systematically ‚Äúwashed out‚Äù so that things like fluid dynamics ‚Äúwork‚Äù. Just sometimes‚Äîlike in studying Brownian motion, or hypersonic flow‚Äîthe molecular dynamics level still ‚Äúshines through‚Äù. But for most ‚Äúhuman purposes‚Äù we can describe fluids just using ordinary fluid dynamics.

So what‚Äôs the analog of this in mathematics? Presumably it‚Äôs that there‚Äôs some kind of ‚Äúgeneral law of mathematics‚Äù that explains why one can so often do mathematics ‚Äúpurely in the large‚Äù. Just like in fluid mechanics there can be ‚Äúcorner-case‚Äù questions that probe down to the ‚Äúmolecular scale‚Äù‚Äîand indeed that‚Äôs where we can expect to see things like undecidability, as a rough analog of situations where we end up tracing the potentially infinite paths of single molecules rather than just looking at ‚Äúoverall fluid effects‚Äù. But somehow in most cases there‚Äôs some much stronger phenomenon at work‚Äîthat effectively aggregates low-level details to allow the kind of ‚Äúbulk description‚Äù that ends up being the essence of what we normally in practice call mathematics.

But is such a phenomenon something formally inevitable, or does it somehow depend on us humans ‚Äúbeing in the loop‚Äù? In the case of the Second Law it‚Äôs crucial that we only get to track coarse-grained features of a gas‚Äîas we humans with our current technology typically do. Because if instead we watched and decoded what every individual molecule does, we wouldn‚Äôt end up identifying anything like the usual bulk ‚ÄúSecond-Law‚Äù behavior. In other words, the emergence of the Second Law is in effect a direct consequence of the fact that it‚Äôs us humans‚Äîwith our limitations on measurement and computation‚Äîwho are observing the gas.

So is something similar happening with mathematics? At the underlying ‚Äúmolecular level‚Äù there‚Äôs a lot going on. But the way we humans think about things, we‚Äôre effectively taking just particular kinds of samples. And those samples turn out to give us ‚Äúgeneral laws of mathematics‚Äù that give us our usual experience of ‚Äúhuman-level mathematics‚Äù.

To ultimately ground this we have to go down to the fully abstract level of the ruliad, but we‚Äôll already see many core effects by looking at mathematics essentially just at a traditional ‚Äúaxiomatic level‚Äù, albeit ‚Äúin bulk‚Äù.

The full story‚Äîand the full correspondence between physics and mathematics‚Äîrequires in a sense ‚Äúgoing below‚Äù the level at which we have recognizable formal axiomatic mathematical structures; it requires going to a level at which we‚Äôre just talking about making everything out of completely abstract elements, which in physics we might interpret as ‚Äúatoms of space‚Äù and in mathematics as some kind of ‚Äúsymbolic raw material‚Äù below variables and operators and everything else familiar in traditional axiomatic mathematics.

The deep correspondence we‚Äôre describing between physics and mathematics might make one wonder to what extent the methods we use in physics can be applied to mathematics, and vice versa. In axiomatic mathematics the emphasis tends to be on looking at particular theorems and seeing how they can be knitted together with proofs. And one could certainly imagine an analogous ‚Äúaxiomatic physics‚Äù in which one does particular experiments, then sees how they can ‚Äúdeductively‚Äù be knitted together. But our impression that there‚Äôs an ‚Äúactual reality‚Äù to physics makes us seek broader laws. And the correspondence between physics and mathematics implied by the ruliad now suggests that we should be doing this in mathematics as well.

What will we find? Some of it in essence just confirms impressions that working pure mathematicians already have. But it provides a definite framework for understanding these impressions and for seeing what their limits may be. It also lets us address questions like why undecidability is so comparatively rare in practical pure mathematics, and why it is so common to discover remarkable correspondences between apparently quite different areas of mathematics. And beyond that, it suggests a host of new questions and approaches both to mathematics and metamathematics‚Äîthat help frame the foundations of the remarkable intellectual edifice that we call mathematics.

2 | The Underlying Structure of Mathematics and Physics

If we ‚Äúdrill down‚Äù to what we‚Äôve called above the ‚Äúmolecular level‚Äù of mathematics, what will we find there? There are many technical details (some of which we‚Äôll discuss later) about the historical conventions of mathematics and its presentation. But in broad outline we can think of there as being a kind of ‚Äúgas‚Äù of ‚Äúmathematical statements‚Äù‚Äîlike 1 + 1 = 2 or x + y = y + x‚Äîrepresented in some specified symbolic language. (And, yes, Wolfram Language provides a well-developed example of what that language can be like.)

But how does the ‚Äúgas of statements‚Äù behave? The essential point is that new statements are derived from existing ones by ‚Äúinteractions‚Äù that implement laws of inference (like that q can be derived from the statement p and the statement ‚Äúp implies q‚Äù). And if we trace the paths by which one statement can be derived from others, these correspond to proofs. And the whole graph of all these derivations is then a representation of the possible historical development of mathematics‚Äîwith slices through this graph corresponding to the sets of statements reached at a given stage.

By talking about things like a ‚Äúgas of statements‚Äù we‚Äôre making this sound a bit like physics. But while in physics a gas consists of actual, physical molecules, in mathematics our statements are just abstract things. But this is where the discoveries of our Physics Project start to be important. Because in our project we‚Äôre ‚Äúdrilling down‚Äù beneath for example the usual notions of space and time to an ‚Äúultimate machine code‚Äù for the physical universe. And we can think of that ultimate machine code as operating on things that are in effect just abstract constructs‚Äîvery much like in mathematics.

In particular, we imagine that space and everything in it is made up of a giant network (hypergraph) of ‚Äúatoms of space‚Äù‚Äîwith each ‚Äúatom of space‚Äù just being an abstract element that has certain relations with other elements. The evolution of the universe in time then corresponds to the application of computational rules that (much like laws of inference) take abstract relations and yield new relations‚Äîthereby progressively updating the network that represents space and everything in it.

But while the individual rules may be very simple, the whole detailed pattern of behavior to which they lead is normally very complicated‚Äîand typically shows computational irreducibility, so that there‚Äôs no way to systematically find its outcome except in effect by explicitly tracing each step. But despite all this underlying complexity it turns out‚Äîmuch like in the case of an ordinary gas‚Äîthat at a coarse-grained level there are much simpler (‚Äúbulk‚Äù) laws of behavior that one can identify. And the remarkable thing is that these turn out to be exactly general relativity and quantum mechanics (which, yes, end up being the same theory when looked at in terms of an appropriate generalization of the notion of space).

But down at the lowest level, is there some specific computational rule that‚Äôs ‚Äúrunning the universe‚Äù? I don‚Äôt think so. Instead, I think that in effect all possible rules are always being applied. And the result is the ruliad: the entangled structure associated with performing all possible computations.

But what then gives us our experience of the universe and of physics? Inevitably we are observers embedded within the ruliad, sampling only certain features of it. But what features we sample are determined by the characteristics of us as observers. And what seem to be critical to have ‚Äúobservers like us‚Äù are basically two characteristics. First, that we are computationally bounded. And second, that we somehow persistently maintain our coherence‚Äîin the sense that we can consistently identify what constitutes ‚Äúus‚Äù even though the detailed atoms of space involved are continually changing.

But we can think of different ‚Äúobservers like us‚Äù as taking different specific samples, corresponding to different reference frames in rulial space, or just different positions in rulial space. These different observers may describe the universe as evolving according to different specific underlying rules. But the crucial point is that the general structure of the ruliad implies that so long as the observers are ‚Äúlike us‚Äù, it‚Äôs inevitable that their perception of the universe will be that it follows things like general relativity and quantum mechanics.

It‚Äôs very much like what happens with a gas of molecules: to an ‚Äúobserver like us‚Äù there are the same gas laws and the same laws of fluid dynamics essentially independent of the detailed structure of the individual molecules.

So what does all this mean for mathematics? The crucial and at first surprising point is that the ideas we‚Äôre describing in physics can in effect immediately be carried over to mathematics. And the key is that the ruliad represents not only all physics, but also all mathematics‚Äîand it shows that these are not just related, but in some sense fundamentally the same.

In the traditional formulation of axiomatic mathematics, one talks about deriving results from particular axiom systems‚Äîsay Peano Arithmetic, or ZFC set theory, or the axioms of Euclidean geometry. But the ruliad in effect represents the entangled consequences not just of specific axiom systems but of all possible axiom systems (as well as all possible laws of inference).

But from this structure that in a sense corresponds to all possible mathematics, how do we pick out any particular mathematics that we‚Äôre interested in? The answer is that just as we are limited observers of the physical universe, so we are also limited observers of the ‚Äúmathematical universe‚Äù.

But what are we like as ‚Äúmathematical observers‚Äù? As I‚Äôll argue in more detail later, we inherit our core characteristics from those we exhibit as ‚Äúphysical observers‚Äù. And that means that when we ‚Äúdo mathematics‚Äù we‚Äôre effectively sampling the ruliad in much the same way as when we ‚Äúdo physics‚Äù.

We can operate in different rulial reference frames, or at different locations in rulial space, and these will correspond to picking out different underlying ‚Äúrules of mathematics‚Äù, or essentially using different axiom systems. But now we can make use of the correspondence with physics to say that we can also expect there to be certain ‚Äúoverall laws of mathematics‚Äù that are the result of general features of the ruliad as perceived by observers like us.

And indeed we can expect that in some formal sense these overall laws will have exactly the same structure as those in physics‚Äîso that in effect in mathematics we‚Äôll have something like the notion of space that we have in physics, as well as formal analogs of things like general relativity and quantum mechanics.

What does this mean? It implies that‚Äîjust as it‚Äôs possible to have coherent ‚Äúhigher-level descriptions‚Äù in physics that don‚Äôt just operate down at the level of atoms of space, so also this should be possible in mathematics. And this in a sense is why we can expect to consistently do what I described above as ‚Äúhuman-level mathematics‚Äù, without usually having to drop down to the ‚Äúmolecular level‚Äù of specific axiomatic structures (or below).

Say we‚Äôre talking about the Pythagorean theorem. Given some particular detailed axiom system for mathematics we can imagine using it to build up a precise‚Äîif potentially very long and pedantic‚Äîrepresentation of the theorem. But let‚Äôs say we change some detail of our axioms, say associated with the way they talk about sets, or real numbers. We‚Äôll almost certainly still be able to build up something we consider to be ‚Äúthe Pythagorean theorem‚Äù‚Äîeven though the details of the representation will be different.

In other words, this thing that we as humans would call ‚Äúthe Pythagorean theorem‚Äù is not just a single point in the ruliad, but a whole cloud of points. And now the question is: what happens if we try to derive other results from the Pythagorean theorem? It might be that each particular representation of the theorem‚Äîcorresponding to each point in the cloud‚Äîwould lead to quite different results. But it could also be that essentially the whole cloud would coherently lead to the same results.

And the claim from the correspondence with physics is that there should be ‚Äúgeneral laws of mathematics‚Äù that apply to ‚Äúobservers like us‚Äù and that ensure that there‚Äôll be coherence between all the different specific representations associated with the cloud that we identify as ‚Äúthe Pythagorean theorem‚Äù.

In physics it could have been that we‚Äôd always have to separately say what happens to every atom of space. But we know that there‚Äôs a coherent higher-level description of space‚Äîin which for example we can just imagine that objects can move while somehow maintaining their identity. And we can now expect that it‚Äôs the same kind of thing in mathematics: that just as there‚Äôs a coherent notion of space in physics where things can for example move without being ‚Äúshredded‚Äù, so also this will happen in mathematics. And this is why it‚Äôs possible to do ‚Äúhigher-level mathematics‚Äù without always dropping down to the lowest level of axiomatic derivations.

It‚Äôs worth pointing out that even in physical space a concept like ‚Äúpure motion‚Äù in which objects can move while maintaining their identity doesn‚Äôt always work. For example, close to a spacetime singularity, one can expect to eventually be forced to see through to the discrete structure of space‚Äîand for any ‚Äúobject‚Äù to inevitably be ‚Äúshredded‚Äù. But most of the time it‚Äôs possible for observers like us to maintain the idea that there are coherent large-scale features whose behavior we can study using ‚Äúbulk‚Äù laws of physics.

And we can expect the same kind of thing to happen with mathematics. Later on, we‚Äôll discuss more specific correspondences between phenomena in physics and mathematics‚Äîand we‚Äôll see the effects of things like general relativity and quantum mechanics in mathematics, or, more precisely, in metamathematics.

But for now, the key point is that we can think of mathematics as somehow being made of exactly the same stuff as physics: they‚Äôre both just features of the ruliad, as sampled by observers like us. And in what follows we‚Äôll see the great power that arises from using this to combine the achievements and intuitions of physics and mathematics‚Äîand how this lets us think about new ‚Äúgeneral laws of mathematics‚Äù, and view the ultimate foundations of mathematics in a different light.

12 | Beyond Substitution: Cosubstitution and Bisubstitution


In making our ‚Äúmetamodel‚Äù of mathematics we‚Äôve been discussing the rewriting of expressions according to rules. But there‚Äôs a subtle issue that we‚Äôve so far avoided, that has to do with the fact that the expressions we‚Äôre rewriting are often themselves patterns that stand for whole classes of expressions. And this turns out to allow for additional kinds of transformations that we‚Äôll call cosubstitution and bisubstitution.


Let‚Äôs talk first about cosubstitution. Imagine we have the expression f[a]. The rule  would do a substitution for a to give f[b]. But if we have the expression f[c] the rule  will do nothing.


Now imagine that we have the expression f[x_]. This stands for a whole class of expressions, including f[a], f[c], etc. For most of this class of expressions, the rule  will do nothing. But in the specific case of f[a], it applies, and gives the result f[b].

There‚Äôs an almost trivial way in which this is true by virtue of the fact that for every edge the system also includes the reverse of that edge. But there‚Äôs a more substantial reason as well: that given any two statements on two different branches, there‚Äôs always a way to combine them using a bisubstitution to get a single statement.


In our Physics Project, the concept of causal invariance‚Äîwhich effectively generalizes confluence‚Äîis an important one, that leads among other things to ideas like relativistic invariance. Later on we‚Äôll discuss the idea that ‚Äúregardless of what order you prove theorems in, you‚Äôll always get the same math‚Äù, and its relationship to causal invariance and to the notion of relativity in metamathematics. But for now the importance of confluence is that it has the potential to simplify automated theorem proving‚Äîbecause in effect it says one can never ultimately ‚Äúmake a wrong turn‚Äù in getting to a particular theorem, or, alternatively, that if one keeps going long enough every path one might take will eventually be able to reach every theorem. 


And indeed this is exactly how things work in the full entailment cone. But the challenge in automated theorem proving is to generate only a tiny part of the entailment cone, yet still ‚Äúget to‚Äù the theorem we want. And in doing this we have to carefully choose which ‚Äúbranches‚Äù we should try to merge using bisubstitution events. In automated theorem proving these bisubstitution events are typically called ‚Äúcritical pair lemmas‚Äù, and there are a variety of strategies for defining an order in which critical pair lemmas should be tried. 


It‚Äôs worth pointing out that there‚Äôs absolutely no guarantee that such procedures will find the shortest proof of any given theorem (or in fact that they‚Äôll find a proof at all with a given amount of computational effort). One can imagine ‚Äúhigher-order proofs‚Äù in which one attempts to transform not just statements of the form , but full proofs (say represented as token-event graphs). 19 | Time, Timelessness and Entailment Fabrics


A fundamental feature of our metamodel of mathematics is the idea that a given set of mathematical statements can entail others. But in this picture what does ‚Äúmathematical progress‚Äù look like?


In analogy with physics one might imagine it would be like the evolution of the universe through time. Logic was originally conceived as a way to characterize human arguments‚Äîin which the concept of ‚Äútruth‚Äù has always seemed quite central. The basic answer is that it produces an ‚Äúexplosion‚Äù in which the entailment fabric can grow to encompass essentially any statement. The ruliad is in a sense a unique and absolute thing. And we might have imagined that it would lead us to a unique and absolute definition of truth in mathematics. But what we‚Äôve seen is that that‚Äôs not the case. And instead our notion of truth is something based on how we sample the ruliad as mathematical observers. But now we must explore what this means about what mathematics as we perceive it can be like.


21 | What Can Human Mathematics Be Like?


The ruliad in a sense contains all structurally possible mathematics‚Äîincluding all mathematical statements, all axiom systems and everything that follows from them. But mathematics as we humans conceive of it is never the whole ruliad; instead it is always just some tiny part that we as mathematical observers sample.


We might imagine, however, that this would mean that there is in a sense a complete arbitrariness to our mathematics‚Äîbecause in a sense we could just pick any part of the ruliad we want. Yes, we might want to start from a specific axiom system. But we might imagine that that axiom system could be chosen arbitrarily, with no further constraint. And that the mathematics we study can therefore be thought of as an essentially arbitrary choice, determined by its detailed history, and perhaps by cognitive or other features of humans.


But there is a crucial additional issue. When we ‚Äúsample our mathematics‚Äù from the ruliad we do it as mathematical observers and ultimately as humans. And it turns out that even very general features of us as mathematical observers turn out to put strong constraints on what we can sample, and how.


When we discussed physics, we said that the central features of observers are their computational boundedness and their assumption of their own persistence through time. In mathematics, observers are again computationally bounded. But now it is not persistence through time that they assume, but rather a certain coherence of accumulated knowledge. 


We can think of a mathematical observer as progressively expanding the entailment fabric that they consider to ‚Äúrepresent mathematics‚Äù. And the question is what they can add to that entailment fabric while still ‚Äúremaining coherent‚Äù as observers. In the previous section, for example, we argued that if the observer adds a statement that can be considered ‚Äúlogically false‚Äù then this will lead to an ‚Äúexplosion‚Äù in the entailment fabric. 


Such a statement is certainly present in the ruliad. But if the observer were to add it, then they wouldn‚Äôt be able to maintain their coherence‚Äîbecause, whimsically put, their mind would necessarily explode. 


In thinking about axiomatic mathematics it‚Äôs been standard to say that any axiom system that‚Äôs ‚Äúreasonable to use‚Äù should at least be consistent (even though, yes, for a given axiom system it‚Äôs in general ultimately undecidable whether this is the case). And certainly consistency is one criterion that we now see is necessary for a ‚Äúmathematical observer like us‚Äù. But one can expect that it‚Äôs not the only criterion.


In other words, although it‚Äôs perfectly possible to write down any axiom system, and even start generating its entailment cone, only some axiom systems may be compatible with ‚Äúmathematical observers like us‚Äù. 


And so, for example, something like the Continuum Hypothesis‚Äîwhich is known to be independent of the ‚Äúestablished axioms‚Äù of set theory‚Äîmay well have the feature that, say, it has to be assumed to be true in order to get a metamathematical structure compatible with mathematical observers like us.


In the case of physics, we know that the general characteristics of observers lead to certain key perceived features and laws of physics. In statistical mechanics, we‚Äôre dealing with ‚Äúcoarse-grained observers‚Äù who don‚Äôt trace and decode the paths of individual molecules, and therefore perceive the Second Law of thermodynamics, fluid dynamics, etc. And in our Physics Project we‚Äôre also dealing with coarse-grained observers who don‚Äôt track all the details of the atoms of space, but instead perceive space as something coherent and effectively continuous. 


And it seems as if in metamathematics there‚Äôs something very similar going on. As we began to discuss in the very first section above, mathematical observers tend to ‚Äúcoarse grain‚Äù metamathematical space. In operational terms, one way they do this is by talking about something like the Pythagorean theorem without always going down to the detailed level of axioms, and for example saying just how real numbers should be defined. And something related is that they tend to concentrate more on mathematical statements and theorems than on their proofs. Later we’ll see how in the context of the ruliad there‚Äôs an even deeper level to which one can go. But the point here is that in actually doing mathematics one tends to operate at the ‚Äúhuman scale‚Äù of talking about mathematical concepts rather than the ‚Äúmolecular-scale details‚Äù of axioms.


But why does this work? Why is one not continually ‚Äúdragged down‚Äù to the detailed axiomatic level‚Äîor below? How come it‚Äôs possible to reason at what we described above as the ‚Äúfluid dynamics‚Äù level, without always having to go down to the detailed ‚Äúmolecular dynamics‚Äù level?


The basic claim is that this works for mathematical observers for essentially the same reason as the perception of space works for physical observers. With the ‚Äúcoarse-graining‚Äù characteristics of the observer, it‚Äôs inevitable that the slice of the ruliad they sample will have the kind of coherence that allows them to operate at a higher level. In other words, mathematics can be done ‚Äúat a human level‚Äù for the same basic reason that we have a ‚Äúhuman-level experience‚Äù of space in physics.


The fact that it works this way depends both on necessary features of the ruliad‚Äîand in general of multicomputation‚Äîas well as on characteristics of us as observers. 


Needless to say, there are ‚Äúcorner cases‚Äù where what we‚Äôve described starts to break down. In physics, for example, the ‚Äúhuman-level experience‚Äù of space breaks down near spacetime singularities. And in mathematics, there are cases where for example undecidability forces one to take a lower-level, more axiomatic and ultimately more metamathematical view. 


But the point is that there are large regions of physical space‚Äîand metamathematical space‚Äîwhere these kinds of issues don‚Äôt come up, and where our assumptions about physical‚Äîand mathematical‚Äîobservers can be maintained. And this is what ultimately allows us to have the ‚Äúhuman-scale‚Äù views of physics and mathematics that we do.

23 | The Physicalized Laws of Mathematics


The concept of the ruliad suggests there is a deep connection between the foundations of mathematics and physics. And now that we have discussed how some of the familiar formalism of mathematics can ‚Äúfit into‚Äù the ruliad, we are ready to use the ‚Äúbridge‚Äù provided by the ruliad to start exploring how to apply some of the successes and intuitions of physics to mathematics.


A foundational part of our everyday experience of physics is our perception that we live in continuous space. But our Physics Project implies that at sufficiently small scales space is actually made of discrete elements‚Äîand it is only because of the coarse-grained way in which we experience it that we perceive it as continuous.


In mathematics‚Äîunlike physics‚Äîwe‚Äôve long thought of the foundations as being based on things like symbolic expressions that have a fundamentally discrete structure. But the crucial point is that this substrate is directly based on the ruliad. And its structure is identical between the foundations of mathematics and physics. But now the commonality of underlying ‚Äúsubstrate‚Äù makes us realize that we should be able to take our experience of physics, and apply it to mathematics. When we do mathematics, though, we‚Äôre sampling this on a much higher level. Foundational approaches to mathematics‚Äîparticularly over the past century or so‚Äîhave almost always been based on axioms and on their fundamentally discrete symbolic structure. At the outset one might not have any reason to think that this higher-level approach could consistently be applied. But this is the first big place where ideas from physics can be used. If both physics and mathematics are based on the ruliad, and if our general characteristics as observers apply in both physics and mathematics, then we can expect that similar features will emerge. The picture is that we as mathematical observers have a certain ‚Äúsize‚Äù in metamathematical space. There‚Äôs another way to think about this, that we alluded to earlier. A key feature of an observer is to have a coherent identity. In practice, there are several ways this happens. 25 | Gravitational and Relativistic Effects in Metamathematics


If metamathematical space is like physical space, does that mean that it has analogs of gravity, and relativity? The answer seems to be ‚Äúyes‚Äù‚Äîand these provide our next examples of physicalized laws of mathematics. 


In the end, we‚Äôre going to be able to talk about at least gravity in a largely ‚Äústatic‚Äù way, referring mostly to the ‚Äúinstantaneous state of metamathematics‚Äù, captured as an entailment fabric. But in leveraging ideas from physics, it‚Äôs important to start off formulating things in terms of the analog of time for metamathematics‚Äîwhich is entailment.


As we‚Äôve discussed above, the entailment cone is the direct analog of the light cone in physics. Starting with some mathematical statement (or, more accurately, some event that transforms it) the forward entailment cone contains all statements (or, more accurately, events) that follow from it. Any possible ‚Äúinstantaneous state of metamathematics‚Äù then corresponds to a ‚Äútransverse slice‚Äù through this entailment cone‚Äîwith the slice in effect being laid out in metamathematical space.


An individual entailment of one statement by another corresponds to a path in the entailment cone, and this path (or, more accurately for accumulative evolution, subgraph) can be thought of as a proof of one statement given another. And in these terms the shortest proof can be thought of as a geodesic in the entailment cone. Given a path in the entailment cone, we can imagine projecting it onto a transverse slice, i.e. onto an entailment fabric. Being able to consistently do this depends on having a certain uniformity in the entailment cone, and in the sequence of ‚Äúmetamathematical hypersurfaces‚Äù that are defined by whatever ‚Äúmetamathematical reference frame‚Äù we‚Äôre using. But assuming, for example, that underlying computational irreducibility successfully generates a kind of ‚Äústatistical uniformity‚Äù that cannot be ‚Äúdecoded‚Äù by the observer, we can expect to have meaningful paths‚Äîand geodesics‚Äîon entailment fabrics.


But what these geodesics are like then depends on the emergent geometry of entailment fabrics. In physics, the limiting geometry of the analog of this for physical space is presumably a fairly simple 3D manifold. For branchial space, it’s more complicated, probably for example being ‚Äúexponential dimensional‚Äù. And for metamathematics, the limiting geometry is also undoubtedly more complicated‚Äîand almost certainly exponential dimensional. 


We‚Äôve argued that we expect metamathematical space to have a certain perceived uniformity. But what will affect this, and therefore potentially modify the local geometry of the space? The basic answer is exactly the same as in our Physics Project. If there‚Äôs ‚Äúmore activity‚Äù somewhere in an entailment fabric, this will in effect lead to ‚Äúmore local connections‚Äù, and thus effective ‚Äúpositive local curvature‚Äù in the emergent geometry of the network. Needless to say, exactly what ‚Äúmore activity‚Äù means is somewhat subtle, especially given that the fabric in which one is looking for this is itself defining the ambient geometry, measures of ‚Äúarea‚Äù, etc.


In our Physics Project we make things more precise by associating ‚Äúactivity‚Äù with energy density, and saying that energy effectively corresponds to the flux of causal edges through spacelike hypersurfaces. So this suggests that we think about an analog of energy in metamathematics: essentially defining it to be the density of update events in the entailment fabric. Or, put another way, energy in metamathematics depends on the ‚Äúdensity of proofs‚Äù going through a region of metamathematical space, i.e. involving particular ‚Äúnearby‚Äù mathematical statements.


There are lots of caveats, subtleties and details. But the notion that ‚Äúactivity AKA energy‚Äù leads to increasing curvature in an emergent geometry is a general feature of the whole multicomputational paradigm that the ruliad captures. And in fact we expect a quantitative relationship between energy density (or, strictly, energy-momentum) and induced curvature of the ‚Äútransversal space‚Äù‚Äîthat corresponds exactly to Einstein’s equations in general relativity. It‚Äôll be more difficult to see this in the metamathematical case because metamathematical space is geometrically more complicated‚Äîand less familiar‚Äîthan physical space.


But even at a qualitative level, it seems very helpful to think in terms of physics and spacetime analogies. The basic phenomenon is that geodesics are deflected by the presence of ‚Äúenergy‚Äù, in effect being ‚Äúattracted to it‚Äù. And this is why we can think of regions of higher energy (or energy-momentum/mass)‚Äîin physics and in metamathematics‚Äîas ‚Äúgenerating gravity‚Äù, and deflecting geodesics towards them. (Needless to say, in metamathematics, as in physics, the vast majority of overall activity is just devoted to knitting together the structure of space, and when gravity is produced, it‚Äôs from slightly increased activity in a particular region.)


(In our Physics Project, a key result is that the same kind of dependence of ‚Äúspatial‚Äù structure on energy happens not only in physical space, but also in branchial space‚Äîwhere there‚Äôs a direct analog of general relativity that basically yields the path integral of quantum mechanics.)


What does this mean in metamathematics? Qualitatively, the implication is that ‚Äúproofs will tend to go through where there‚Äôs a higher density of proofs‚Äù. Or, in an analogy, if you want to drive from one place to another, it‚Äôll be more efficient if you can do at least part of your journey on a freeway.


One question to ask about metamathematical space is whether one can always get from any place to any other. In other words, starting from one area of mathematics, can one somehow derive all others? A key issue here is whether the area one starts from is computation universal. Propositional logic is not, for example. So if one starts from it, one is essentially trapped, and cannot reach other areas.


But results in mathematical logic have established that most traditional areas of axiomatic mathematics are in fact computation universal (and the Principle of Computational Equivalence suggests that this will be ubiquitous). But a big question is whether the ‚Äúproof path‚Äù is ‚Äúbig enough‚Äù to be appropriate for a ‚Äúmathematical observer like us‚Äù. In practical pure mathematics, this tends to be an issue of whether there is an ‚Äúelegant proof using high-level concepts‚Äù, or whether one has to drop down to a very detailed level that‚Äôs more like low-level computer code, or the output of an automated theorem proving system. But there‚Äôs another point here as well. If one looks at an individual proof path, it can be computationally irreducible to find out where the path goes, and the question of whether it ever reaches a particular destination can be undecidable. Later we‚Äôll discuss the dichotomy between explorations of computational systems that routinely run into undecidability‚Äîand the typical experience of pure mathematics, where undecidability is rarely encountered in practice. Of course, by asking specific questions‚Äîabout metamathematics, or, say, about very specific equations‚Äîit‚Äôs still perfectly possible to force tracing of individual ‚Äúlow-level‚Äù proof paths. And in a sense we can see this as an extension of our first physicalized law of mathematics: not only is higher-level mathematics possible, but it‚Äôs ubiquitously so, with the result that, at least in terms of the questions a mathematical observer would readily formulate, phenomena like undecidability are not generically seen.


But even though undecidability may not be directly visible to a mathematical observer, its underlying presence is still crucial in coherently ‚Äúknitting together‚Äù metamathematical space. There are many details to work out, but the qualitative picture can be developed further. In a sense this implies that the long-term future of mathematics is strangely similar to the long-term future of our physical universe. We‚Äôve talked at some length about the ‚Äúgravitational‚Äù structure of metamathematical space. But what about seemingly simpler things like special relativity? 27 | Invented or Discovered? How Mathematics Relates to Humans


It‚Äôs an old and oft-asked question: is mathematics ultimately something that is invented, or something that is discovered? Or, put another way: is mathematics something arbitrarily set up by us humans, or something inevitable and fundamental and in a sense ‚Äúpreexisting‚Äù, that we merely get to explore? In the past it‚Äôs seemed as if these were two fundamentally incompatible possibilities. But the framework we‚Äôve built here in a sense blends them both into a rather unexpected synthesis.


The starting point is the idea that mathematics‚Äîlike physics‚Äîis rooted in the ruliad, which is a representation of formal necessity. Actual mathematics as we ‚Äúexperience‚Äù it is‚Äîlike physics‚Äîbased on the particular sampling we make of the ruliad. But then the crucial point is that very basic characteristics of us as ‚Äúobservers‚Äù are sufficient to constrain that experience to be our general mathematics‚Äîor our physics.


At some level we can say that ‚Äúmathematics is always there‚Äù‚Äîbecause every aspect of it is ultimately encoded in the ruliad. But in another sense we can say that the mathematics we have is all ‚Äúup to us‚Äù‚Äîbecause it‚Äôs based on how we sample the ruliad. But the point is that that sampling is not somehow ‚Äúarbitrary‚Äù: if we‚Äôre talking about mathematics for us humans then it‚Äôs us ultimately doing the sampling, and the sampling is inevitably constrained by general features of our nature.


A major discovery from our Physics Project is that it doesn‚Äôt take much in the way of constraints on the observer to deeply constrain the laws of physics they will perceive. And similarly we posit here that for ‚Äúobservers like us‚Äù there will inevitably be general (‚Äúphysicalized‚Äù) laws of mathematics, that make mathematics inevitably have the general kinds of characteristics we perceive it to have (such as the possibility of doing mathematics at a high level, without always having to drop down to an ‚Äúatomic‚Äù level).


Particularly over the past century there‚Äôs been the idea that mathematics can be specified in terms of axiom systems, and that these axiom systems can somehow be ‚Äúinvented at will‚Äù. But our framework does two things. First, it says that ‚Äúfar below‚Äù axiom systems is the raw ruliad, which in a sense represents all possible axiom systems. And second, it says that whatever axiom systems we perceive to be ‚Äúoperating‚Äù will be ones that we as observers can pick out from the underlying structure of the ruliad.


At a formal level we can ‚Äúinvent‚Äù an arbitrary axiom system (and it‚Äôll be somewhere in the ruliad), but only certain axiom systems will be ones that describe what we as ‚Äúmathematical observers‚Äù can perceive. In a physics setting we might construct some formal physical theory that talks about detailed patterns in the atoms of space (or molecules in a gas), but the kind of ‚Äúcoarse-grained‚Äù observations that we can make won‚Äôt capture these. Put another way, observers like us can perceive certain kinds of things, and can describe things in terms of these perceptions. But with the wrong kind of theory‚Äîor ‚Äúaxioms‚Äù‚Äîthese descriptions won‚Äôt be sufficient‚Äîand only an observer who‚Äôs ‚Äúshredded‚Äù down to a more ‚Äúatomic‚Äù level will be able to track what‚Äôs going on.


There‚Äôs lots of different possible math‚Äîand physics‚Äîin the ruliad. But observers like us can only ‚Äúaccess‚Äù a certain type. Some putative alien not like us might access a different type‚Äîand might end up with both a different math and a different physics. Deep underneath they‚Äîlike us‚Äîwould be talking about the ruliad. But they‚Äôd be taking different samples of it, and describing different aspects of it.


For much of the history of mathematics there was a close alignment between the mathematics that was done and what we perceive in the world. For example, Euclidean geometry‚Äîwith its whole axiomatic structure‚Äîwas originally conceived just as an idealization of geometrical things that we observe about the world. But by the late 1800s the idea had emerged that one could create ‚Äúdisembodied‚Äù axiomatic systems with no particular grounding in our experience in the world. 


And, yes, there are many possible disembodied axiom systems that one can set up. And in doing ruliology and generally exploring the computational universe it‚Äôs interesting to investigate what they do. But the point is that this is something quite different from mathematics as mathematics is normally conceived. Because in a sense mathematics‚Äîlike physics‚Äîis a ‚Äúmore human‚Äù activity that‚Äôs based on what ‚Äúobservers like us‚Äù make of the raw formal structure that is ultimately embodied in the ruliad.


When it comes to physics there are, it seems, two crucial features of ‚Äúobservers like us‚Äù. First, that we‚Äôre computationally bounded. And second, that we have the perception that we‚Äôre persistent‚Äîand have a definite and continuous thread of experience. At the level of atoms of space, we‚Äôre in a sense constantly being ‚Äúremade‚Äù. But we nevertheless perceive it as always being the ‚Äúsame us‚Äù.


This single seemingly simple assumption has far-reaching consequences. For example, it leads us to experience a single thread of time. And from the notion that we maintain a continuity of experience from every successive moment to the next we are inexorably led to the idea of a perceived continuum‚Äînot only in time, but also for motion and in space. And when combined with intrinsic features of the ruliad and of multicomputation in general, what comes out in the end is a surprisingly precise description of how we‚Äôll perceive our universe to operate‚Äîthat seems to correspond exactly with known core laws of physics.


What does that kind of thinking tell us about mathematics? The basic point is that‚Äîsince in the end both relate to humans‚Äîthere is necessarily a close correspondence between physical and mathematical observers. Both are computationally bounded. And the assumption of persistence in time for physical observers becomes for mathematical observers the concept of maintaining coherence as more statements are accumulated. And when combined with intrinsic features of the ruliad and multicomputation this then turns out to imply the kind of physicalized laws of mathematics that we‚Äôve discussed.


In a formal axiomatic view of mathematics one just imagines that one invents axioms and sees their consequences. But what we‚Äôre describing here is a view of mathematics that is ultimately just about the ways that we as mathematical observers sample and experience the ruliad. And if we use axiom systems it has to be as a kind of ‚Äúintermediate language‚Äù that helps us make a slightly higher-level description of some corner of the raw ruliad. But actual ‚Äúhuman-level‚Äù mathematics‚Äîlike human-level physics‚Äîoperates at a higher level.


Our everyday experience of the physical world gives us the impression that we have a kind of ‚Äúdirect access‚Äù to many foundational features of physics, like the existence of space and the phenomenon of motion. But our Physics Project implies that these are not concepts that are in any sense ‚Äúalready there‚Äù; they are just things that emerge from the raw ruliad when you ‚Äúparse‚Äù it in the kinds of ways observers like us do. 


In mathematics it‚Äôs less obvious (at least to all but perhaps experienced pure mathematicians) that there‚Äôs ‚Äúdirect access‚Äù to anything. But in our view of mathematics here, it‚Äôs ultimately just like physics‚Äîand ultimately also rooted in the ruliad, but sampled not by physical observers but by mathematical ones. 


So from this point view there‚Äôs just as much that’s ‚Äúreal‚Äù underneath mathematics as there is underneath physics. The mathematics is sampled slightly differently (though very similarly)‚Äîbut we should not in any sense consider it ‚Äúfundamentally more abstract‚Äù. 


When we think of ourselves as entities within the ruliad, we can build up what we might consider a ‚Äúfully abstract‚Äù description of how we get our ‚Äúexperience‚Äù of physics. And we can basically do the same thing for mathematics. So if we take the commonsense point of view that physics fundamentally exists ‚Äúfor real‚Äù, we‚Äôre forced into the same point of view for mathematics. In other words, if we say that the physical universe exists, so must we also say that in some fundamental sense, mathematics also exists.


It‚Äôs not something we as humans ‚Äújust make‚Äù, but it is something that is made through our particular way of observing the ruliad, that is ultimately defined by our particular characteristics as observers, with our particular core assumptions about the world, our particular kinds of sensory experience, and so on.


So what can we say in the end about whether mathematics is ‚Äúinvented‚Äù or ‚Äúdiscovered‚Äù? It is neither. Its underpinnings are the ruliad, whose structure is a matter of formal necessity. But its perceived form for us is determined by our intrinsic characteristics as observers. We neither get to ‚Äúarbitrarily invent‚Äù what‚Äôs underneath, nor do we get to ‚Äúarbitrarily discover‚Äù what‚Äôs already there. The mathematics we see is the result of a combination of formal necessity in the underlying ruliad, and the particular forms of perception that we‚Äîas entities like us‚Äîhave. Putative aliens could have quite different mathematics, but not because the underlying ruliad is any different for them, but because their forms of perception might be different. And it‚Äôs the same with physics: even though they ‚Äúlive in the same physical universe‚Äù their perception of the laws of physics could be quite different.


28 | What Axioms Can There Be for Human Mathematics?


When they were first developed in antiquity the axioms of Euclidean geometry were presumably intended basically as a kind of ‚Äútightening‚Äù of our everyday impressions of geometry‚Äîthat would aid in being able to deduce what was true in geometry. But by the mid-1800s‚Äîbetween non-Euclidean geometry, group theory, Boolean algebra and quaternions‚Äîit had become clear that there was a range of abstract axiom systems one could in principle consider. And by the time of Hilbert‚Äôs program around 1900 the pure process of deduction was in effect being viewed as an end in itself‚Äîand indeed the core of mathematics‚Äîwith axiom systems being seen as ‚Äústarter material‚Äù pretty much just ‚Äúdetermined by convention‚Äù.


In practice even today very few different axiom systems are ever commonly used‚Äîand indeed in A New Kind of Science I was able to list essentially all of them comfortably on a couple of pages. But why these axiom systems and not others? Despite the idea that axiom systems could ultimately be arbitrary, the concept was still that in studying some particular area of mathematics one should basically have an axiom system that would provide a ‚Äútight specification‚Äù of whatever mathematical object or structure one was trying to talk about. And so, for example, the Peano axioms are what became used for talking about arithmetic-style operations on integers.


In 1931, however, G√∂del‚Äôs theorem showed that actually these axioms weren‚Äôt strong enough to constrain one to be talking only about integers: there were also other possible models of the axiom system, involving all sorts of exotic ‚Äúnon-standard arithmetic‚Äù. (And moreover, there was no finite way to ‚Äúpatch‚Äù this issue.) In other words, even though the Peano axioms had been invented‚Äîlike Euclid‚Äôs axioms for geometry‚Äîas a way to describe a definite ‚Äúintuitive‚Äù mathematical thing (in this case, integers) their formal axiomatic structure ‚Äúhad a life of its own‚Äù that extended (in some sense, infinitely) beyond its original intended purpose.


Both geometry and arithmetic in a sense had foundations in everyday experience. But for set theory dealing with infinite sets there was never an obvious intuitive base rooted in everyday experience. Some extrapolations from finite sets were clear. But in covering infinite sets various axioms (like the Axiom of Choice) were gradually added to capture what seemed like ‚Äúreasonable‚Äù mathematical assertions.


But one example whose status for a long time wasn‚Äôt clear was the Continuum Hypothesis‚Äîwhich asserts that the ‚Äúnext distinct possible cardinality‚Äù  after the cardinality  of the integers is : the cardinality of real numbers (i.e. of ‚Äúthe continuum‚Äù). Was this something that followed from previously accepted axioms of set theory? And if it was added, would it even be consistent with them? In the early 1960s it was established that actually the Continuum Hypothesis is independent of the other axioms.


With the axiomatic view of the foundations of mathematics that‚Äôs been popular for the past century or so it seems as if one could, for example, just choose at will whether to include the Continuum Hypothesis (or its negation) as an axiom in set theory. But with the approach to the foundations of mathematics that we‚Äôve developed here, this is no longer so clear.


Recall that in our approach, everything is ultimately rooted in the ruliad‚Äîwith whatever mathematics observers like us ‚Äúexperience‚Äù just being the result of the particular sampling we do of the ruliad. And in this picture, axiom systems are a particular representation of fairly low-level features of the sampling we do of the raw ruliad.

30 | Some Historical (and Philosophical) Background


The human activity that we now call ‚Äúmathematics‚Äù can presumably trace its origins into prehistory. What might have started as ‚Äúa single goat‚Äù, ‚Äúa pair of goats‚Äù, etc. became a story of abstract numbers that could be indicated purely by things like tally marks. The tradition of philosophy that emerged in Greek times saw mathematics as a kind of reasoning. But while much of arithmetic (apart from issues of infinity and infinitesimals) could be thought of in explicit calculational ways, precise geometry immediately required an idealization‚Äîspecifically the concept of a point having no extent, or equivalently, the continuity of space. And in an effort to reason on top of this idealization, there emerged the idea of defining axioms and making abstract deductions from them.


But what kind of a thing actually was mathematics? Plato talked about things we sense in the external world, and things we conceptualize in our internal thoughts. But he considered mathematics to be at its core an example of a third kind of thing: something from an abstract world of ideal forms. And with our current thinking, there is an immediate resonance between this concept of ideal forms and the concept of the ruliad. 


But for most of the past two millennia of the actual development of mathematics, questions about what it ultimately was lay in the background. Through the 1700s mathematics as a practical field was viewed as some kind of precise idealization of features of the world‚Äîthough with an increasingly elaborate tower of formal derivations constructed in it. But if mathematics was to be formalized, what should its underlying primitives be? Meanwhile, starting around 1900, Hilbert took a slightly different path, essentially representing everything with what we would now call symbolic expressions, and setting up axioms as relations between these. But, OK, so how has mathematics actually conducted itself over the past century? There‚Äôs been significant emphasis placed on the idea of formal deduction and proof‚Äîbut not so much in terms of formally building up from axioms as in terms of giving narrative expositions that help humans understand why some theorem might follow from other things they know.
