But a key (and in some ways very surprising) point is that the ruliad can be viewed as the basis of both physics and mathematics. In some sense, physics and mathematics are at their core the same thing. They only ‚Äúappear different‚Äù to us because the way we ‚Äúobserve‚Äù them is different.

Knowing that the ruliad contains so many different computations, one might imagine that it would show no particular uniformity or homogeneity. What’s beyond the Ruliad?


In our Physics Project we usually talk of the universe ‚Äúevolving through time‚Äù (albeit with many entangled threads of history). A very important claim about the ruliad is that it‚Äôs unique. Yes, it can be coordinatized and sampled in different ways. But ultimately there‚Äôs only one ruliad. Communicating across Rulial Space

The concept of the ruliad arose from our efforts to find a fundamental theory of physics. But now that we know about the ruliad, what does it tell us about a fundamental theory?

Ultimately they must be determined by the details of how we sample the ruliad. And a prominent part of that is simply: Where in the ruliad are we? What does all this mean? At some level it‚Äôs saying that the way we are as observers is what makes us attribute certain rules to our universe. Let‚Äôs look at the logical structure of what we‚Äôre saying. Much of our perception of the universe is based on our raw biological structure‚Äîthe way our sensory organs (like our eyes) work, as well as the way our brains integrate the inputs we get. So what could actually be going on? Thinking in terms of the ruliad suggests an answer. Our radio telescopes might be able to detect signals from far away in physical space. But our putative aliens might not only live far away in physical space, but also in rulial space.


Put another way, the ‚Äúalien civilization‚Äù might be sampling aspects of the ruliad‚Äîand in effect the universe‚Äîthat are utterly different from those we‚Äôre used to. That different sampling might be happening right down at the level of atoms of space, or it might be that the rulial distance from us to the aliens is small enough that there‚Äôs enough ‚Äúshared description language‚Äù that the alien civilization might rise to the level of seeming like some kind of ‚Äúnoise‚Äù relative to our view of ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs important in the universe‚Äù.


We might wonder how far apart what we could consider ‚Äúalien civilizations‚Äù would be in physical space. But what we now realize is that we also have to consider how far apart they might be in rulial space. And just like in exploring physical space we can imagine building better spacecraft or better telescopes, so also we can imagine building better ways to reach across rulial space. 


We‚Äôre so used to physical space that it seems to us very concrete to reach across it. Of course, in our Physics Project, things like motion in physical space end up‚Äîlike everything else‚Äîbeing pure computational processes. And from this point of view, reaching across rulial space is ultimately no more abstract‚Äîeven though today we would describe it in terms of ‚Äúdoing (abstract) computations‚Äù rather than ‚Äúmoving in space‚Äù.


Relative to our own physical size, the universe already seems like a vast place. But the full ruliad is even incredibly more vast. And we are likely much tinier in rulial space relative to the whole universe than we are in physical space. From the Principle of Computational Equivalence we can expect that there‚Äôs ultimately no lack of raw computational sophistication out there‚Äîbut thinking in terms of the ruliad, the issue is whether what‚Äôs going on is close enough to us in rulial space that we can successfully see it as an ‚Äúalien civilization‚Äù.


One test of rulial distance might be to ask whether our putative aliens perceive the same laws of physics for the universe that we do. We know that at least the general forms of those laws depend only on what seem to us rather loose conditions. But to get good alignment presumably requires at the very least that we and the aliens are somehow ‚Äúcomparable in size‚Äù not only in physical space (and branchial space), but also in rulial space. 


It‚Äôs humbling how difficult it is to imagine the universe from the point of view of an alien at a different place in rulial space. But for example if the alien is big compared to us in rulial space, we can say that they‚Äôll inevitably have a version of science that seems to us much ‚Äúvaguer‚Äù than ours. Because if they maintain a coherent thread of experience, they‚Äôll have to conflate more distant paths in rulial space, on which the universe will do things that are ‚Äúmore different‚Äù than what we‚Äôre used to. (And, yes, there should be rulial analogs of quantum phenomena, associated for example with conflated paths that diverge far in rulial space.)


What would it mean operationally for there to be an alien civilization perhaps nearby in physical space but at a distance in rulial space? Basically the alien civilization will be ‚Äúoperating‚Äù in features of the universe that our parsing of the universe just doesn‚Äôt pick up. As a simple analogy, our view of, for example, a box of gas might be that it‚Äôs something with a certain temperature and pressure. But a different ‚Äúparsing‚Äù of that system might identify a whole world of detailed motions of molecules that with respect to that parsing can be viewed as a vast ‚Äúalien civilization‚Äù. Of course, the situation is much more extreme when it comes to the whole ruliad, and all the paths of history and configurations of atoms of space that it represents.


Relative to the whole ruliad, our civilization and our experience have carved out an extremely tiny piece. And what we‚Äôre thinking of as ‚Äúalien civilizations‚Äù might also have carved out their own tiny pieces. And while we‚Äôre all ‚Äúliving in the same ruliad‚Äù, we might no more be able to detect each other or communicate (and likely very much less) than we can across vast distances in physical space. 


What of the future? The future of our civilization might well be a story of mapping out more of rulial space. If we continue to invent new technology, explore new ideas and generally broaden our ways of thinking and perceiving, we will gradually‚Äîalbeit in tiny steps‚Äîmap out more of rulial space. How far can we get? The ultimate limit is determined by the maximum rulial speed. But if we expect to maintain our character as ‚Äúobservers like us‚Äù, we‚Äôll no doubt be limited to something much less.


Among other issues, moving in rulial space involves doing computation. (The ultimate scale is set by the ‚Äúprocessing power‚Äù of the universe‚Äîwhich defines the maximum rulial speed.) But ‚Äúdensity of computation‚Äù effectively corresponds to a generalized version of mass‚Äîand is for example a source of ‚Äúgeneralized gravity‚Äù. And it could be that to ‚Äúmove any significant distance‚Äù in rulial space, we‚Äôd have to ‚Äúexperience enough generalized gravity‚Äù that we could never maintain things like the kind of coherence we need to be an ‚Äúobserver like us‚Äù.


Put another way: yes, it might in principle be possible to ‚Äúreach out in rulial space‚Äù and ‚Äúcontact the rulial aliens‚Äù. But it might be that doing so would require us to be so different from the way we currently are that we wouldn‚Äôt recognize anything like consciousness or anything that really makes us ‚Äúidentifiably us‚Äù. And if this is so, we are in a sense limited to experiencing the ruliad ‚Äúon our own‚Äù from our particular place in rulial space, forever isolated from ‚Äúalien civilizations‚Äù elsewhere in rulial space.


Conceptual Implications of the Ruliad


What does the concept of the ruliad mean for the fundamental way we think about things like science? The typical conception of ‚Äúwhat science does‚Äù is that it‚Äôs about us figuring out‚Äîas ‚Äúobjectively‚Äù as we can‚Äîhow the world happens to be. But the concept of the ruliad in a sense turns this on its head. 


Because it says that at some ultimate level, everything is a matter of abstract necessity. And it‚Äôs just our ‚Äúparsing‚Äù of it that defines the subject matter of what we call science. We might have thought that the science of the universe was just something that‚Äôs ‚Äúout there‚Äù. But what we‚Äôre realizing is that instead in some fundamental sense, it‚Äôs all ‚Äúon us‚Äù.


But does that mean that there‚Äôs no ‚Äúobjective truth‚Äù, and nothing that can robustly be said about the universe without ‚Äúpassing it through us‚Äù? Well, no. Because what we‚Äôve discovered through our Physics Project is that actually there are quite global things that can (‚Äúobjectively‚Äù) be said about our universe and the laws it follows, as perceived by observers like us. 


We don‚Äôt have to know in detail about us humans and the particular ways we perceive things. All we need are some general features‚Äîparticularly that we are computationally bounded, and that we have a certain persistence and coherence. And this is all it takes to deduce some quite specific statements about how our universe operates, at least as we perceive it.


So in a sense what this means is that there is a large ‚Äúzone of objectivity‚Äù; a large set of choices for how we could be that will still lead us to the same ‚Äúobjective truth‚Äù about our universe. But if we go far enough away in our mechanism for ‚Äúparsing the ruliad‚Äù, this will no longer be the case. From our current vantage point, we‚Äôd no doubt then be hard-pressed to recognize how we‚Äôre ‚Äúdoing the parsing‚Äù, but the results we‚Äôd get would no longer give us the same laws of physics or general perception of the universe that we‚Äôre used to.


This view of things has all sorts of implications for various long-discussed philosophical issues. But it‚Äôs also a view that has precise scientific consequences. And these don‚Äôt just relate to physics. Because the ruliad is really a general object that represents the entangled behavior of all possible abstract rules. When we think of ourselves as observers embedded within this object, it means that for us things are actualized, and we have what we call physics. But we can also imagine sampling the ruliad in different ways. 


Some of those ways correspond to mathematics (or metamathematics). Some correspond to theoretical computer science. The ruliad is the single object that underlies all of them. And which of them we‚Äôre talking about just depends on how we imagine we‚Äôre sampling or parsing the ruliad, and how we‚Äôre describing what we‚Äôre observing.


With this degree of generality and universality, it‚Äôs inevitable that the ruliad must be a complicated object; in fact, in a sense it must encapsulate all possible achievable complexity. But what‚Äôs important is that we now have a definite concept of the ruliad, as something we can study and analyze.


It‚Äôs not simple to do this. The ruliad is at some level an object of great and perhaps supremely elegant abstract regularity. But for us to get any concrete handle on it and its structure, we need to break it down into some kind of ‚Äúdigestible slices‚Äù which inevitably lose much of its abstract regularity. 


And we‚Äôre just at the beginning of seeing how best to ‚Äúunpack‚Äù and ‚Äúpick through‚Äù the ruliad. With explicit computations, we can only chip away at the very simplest approximations to the ruliad. In a sense it‚Äôs a tribute to the naturalness and inevitability of the ruliad that it‚Äôs so closely related to some of the most advanced abstract mathematical methods we know so far. But again, even with these methods we‚Äôre barely scratching the surface of the ruliad and what it contains.


The theoretical exploration of the ruliad will be a long and difficult journey. But the incredible generality and universality of the ruliad means that every piece of progress is likely to have exceptionally powerful consequences. In some sense the exploration of the ruliad can be seen as the encapsulated expression of everything it means to do theoretical investigation: a kind of ultimately abstract limit of theoretical science and more.


For me, the ruliad in a sense builds on a tower of ideas, that include the computational paradigm in general, the exploration of the computational universe of simple programs, the Principle of Computational Equivalence, our Physics Project and the notion of multicomputation. But even with all of these it‚Äôs still a significant further jump in abstraction. And one whose consequences will take considerable time to unfold.


But for now it‚Äôs exciting to have at least been able to define this thing I call the ruliad, and to start seeing some of its unprecedentedly broad and deep implications. 




Appendix: The Case of the “Multiplicad”


As a very simple example of something like the ruliad, we can consider what we might call the ‚Äúmultiplicad‚Äù: a rulial multiway system based on integers, in which the rules simply multiply by successive integers:

As mentioned at the beginning, the multiplicad is presumably not on its own capable of giving us the full ruliad. But if we change the underlying rules‚Äîprobably even just inserting addition as well as multiplication‚Äîwe‚Äôll potentially get a system that is capable of universal computation, and which can therefore generate the full ruliad. Needless to say, the particular representation of the ruliad obtained by the kind of ‚Äúnumerical processes‚Äù that we‚Äôve used here may be utterly different from any representation that we would recognize from our perception of the physical universe.

Je sais, il y a une source VLC dans OBS, mais je n’ai jamais r√©ussi √† la faire fonctionner correctement. Donc je suis parti sur VLC, mais charg√© √† l’ext√©rieur d’OBS.

J’ai donc rajout√© un petit & √† la fin de la commande pour que OBS reprenne imm√©diatement la main et n’attende pas comme un con que VLC ait termin√©.

Ce qui est cool avec tout √ßa, c’est que √ßa ouvre un monde de possibilit√© pour augmenter et piloter OBS tout en script. C’est donc √† creuser. Il ne me manque plus que les bonnes id√©es maintenant.

items.content:
— Article en partenariat avec Talent.io —

Certains pensent que le monde se divise en deux avec d’un c√¥t√© le bien et de l’autre le mal. Mais la v√©rit√© est ailleurs surtout pour les d√©veloppeurs qui savent que le monde se divise en r√©alit√© entre le Frontend et le Backend.

Et pour que ces 2 faces d’une m√™me pi√®ce puissent ¬´¬†discuter¬†¬ª, il nous faut des API. API, √ßa veut dire Application Programming Interface et c’est tout simplement un ensemble d’instructions permettant aux applications de communiquer entre elles. Maintenant des types d’API, il y en a des tonnes, mais je vous propose qu’aujourd’hui on s’int√©resse aux API qui respectent le standard architectural REST.

En effet, quand on travaille en tant que d√©veloppeur, on ne peut pas passer √† c√¥t√© des API REST, tant cette pratique est tr√®s r√©pandue. Si vous d√©butez dans votre m√©tier, c’est forcement quelque chose que vous devez apprendre et maitriser. De la m√™me mani√®re, quand on d√©bute sa carri√®re de d√©veloppeur ou qu’on a d√©j√† beaucoup d’ann√©es au compteur mais qu’on ne conna√Æt pas sa valeur sur le march√© de l’emploi, il est bon de conna√Ætre la grille des salaires en France. √áa tombe bien puisque talent.io a mis en ligne une √©tude des salaires de la tech en 2022 pour que vous puissiez d√©terminer si votre salaire est correct ou sous √©valu√©.

Je vous invite √† vous plonger dedans afin de savoir o√π vous vous situez sur cette grille des salaires.

C’est quoi une API RESTful ?

REST, √ßa veut dire ¬´¬†Representational State Transfer¬†¬ª. Lorsqu’une API respecte les contraintes de REST, on parle alors d’une API RESTful.

Quand un d√©veloppeur veut cr√©er une API RESTful, il doit alors respecter les contraintes √©dict√©es par REST, notamment sur le fait que son API doit fonctionner au travers du protocole HTTP et de ses verbes (GET, POST…etc.) et que les requ√™tes et les r√©ponses de l’API soient dans un format texte tels que JSON, HTML, XML…etc.

Les API RESTful sont alors mises √† disposition des applications via ce qu’on appelle des endpoints. Un endpoint est un assemblage de 2 choses : une URI et un verbe HTTP.

Admettons que j’ai une API qui permette de lister des utilisateurs, mais √©galement d’en cr√©er des nouveaux.

L’URI de mon API est la suivante : 

https://url.com/api/user

Le but du jeu, c’est d’appeler par exemple ce endpoint avec le verbe GET pour obtenir une liste de tous les utilisateurs.

GET: /user/

Ou pour ajouter un nouvel utilisateur, on peut utiliser le verbe POST comme ceci, en transmettant un bout de JSON contenant toutes les informations li√©es √† l’utilisateur qu’on souhaite cr√©er (nom, pr√©nom…etc.) : 

POST: /user/

L’id√©e l√†, c’est de vous montrer qu’on peut interagir avec l’API √† l’aide de diff√©rents verbes HTTP. Get peut √™tre assimil√© au verbe ¬´¬†lire¬†¬ª, POST au verbe ¬´¬†cr√©er¬†¬ª, PUT et PATCH au verbe ¬´¬†Mettre √† jour¬†¬ª et DELETE au verbe ¬´¬†supprimer¬†¬ª. C’est aussi simple que cela. Et en retour le serveur peut alors r√©pondre avec des codes de status HTTP classiques comme 200, 201, 2002…etc. pour dire que tout est OK, ou des codes de redirection 3xx, d’erreur client 4xx ou d’erreur serveur 5xx.

En ce qui concerne le format utilis√© par les requ√™tes et les r√©ponses, vous pouvez utiliser du texte, peu importe son format (html, xml.etc.), mais par convention, on utilise surtout du JSON (JavaScript Object Notation).

Et JSON ?

Le JSON a la particularit√© d’√™tre facile √† lire et √† √©crire pour les humains et est utilis√© pour enregistrer des donn√©es dans des bases de donn√©es, mais √©galement pour transmettre ces donn√©es entre les applications. C’est pourquoi on l’utilise dans les API RESTful.

Le JSON est une collection de paires nom / valeur qui sont ordonn√©es dans une liste. Ainsi les valeurs contenues dans le JSON peuvent √™tre une chaine de caract√®re (string), un nombre, mais √©galement des objets JSON, des tableaux de valeurs (Array), des bool√©ens (true / false) ou la fameuse valeur null.

Voil√† concernant les grands principes des API RESTful.

Comment cr√©er votre premi√®re API RESTful ?

Maintenant je vous propose qu’on apprenne √† en cr√©er une de z√©ro. Vous allez voir, c’est super simple.

Pour cette d√©mo, j’ai choisi d’utiliser Python comme d’habitude. Et je vais importer dans mon code le framework Flask qui va me permettre de faire monter mon API RESTful tr√®s facilement. Installez Flask comme ceci :

pip3 install flask-restful

Pour tester l’API, nous allons utiliser un outil qui permet √† la fois de balancer nos requ√™tes et de voir si les r√©ponses correspondent bien. L’un des plus connus s’appelle Postman et c’est gratuit en version de base pour tester. L’application Desktop de Postman est disponible ici.

Ensuite, nous allons d√©finir ce que va faire notre API. Ce sera quelque chose d’assez simple permettant de cr√©er, supprimer, lire et mettre √† jour des donn√©es. Admettons que j’ai un site sur lequel je dois r√©f√©rencer des produits. Chacun de ces produits aura un id, un nom, un prix et une cat√©gorie.

Le code de votre premi√®re API

Je vais donc cr√©er un fichier productAPI.py et je vais importer Flask comme ceci avec ses imports sp√©cifiques aux API et au parsing JSON :

from flask import Flask
from flask_restful import Resource, Api, reqparse

app = Flask(__name__)
api = Api(app)

Puis je vais cr√©er une esp√®ce de mini base de donn√©es JSON directement dans mon code afin d’y r√©f√©rencer mes produits :

products = [
    { "id": 1, "name": "Stylo 4 couleurs", "price": 10, "category": "Papeterie" },
    { "id": 2, "name": "Cahier vert", "price": 20, "category": "Papeterie" },
    { "id": 3, "name": "T√©l√©vision 4K", "price": 30, "category": "Tech" },
    { "id": 4, "name": "Souris sans fil", "price": 40, "category": "Tech" },
    { "id": 5, "name": "Ananas", "price": 50, "category": "Alimentaire" },
    { "id": 6, "name": "Kinder Bueno", "price": 60, "category": "Alimentaire" },
    { "id": 7, "name": "Chemise de pr√©sident", "price": 70, "category": "Textile" },
    { "id": 8, "name": "T-shirt de punk", "price": 80, "category": "Textile" },
    { "id": 9, "name": "Tournevis bleu", "price": 90, "category": "Bricolage" },
    { "id": 10, "name": "Marteau rouge", "price": 100, "category": "Bricolage" }
    ]

Maintenant on va cr√©er une classe Product qui sera vu comme un endpoint au niveau de notre API. Et dans cette class, nous allons placer nos 4 fonctions correspondantes aux 4 verbes HTTP dont je vous ai parl√© plus haut.

class Product(Resource):

    def get(self, id):

    def post(self, id):

    def put(self, id):

    def delete(self, id):

La structure de base de notre API est OK. Maintenant, on va d√©finir chacune de ces fonctions en commen√ßant par la fonction get utilis√©e pour r√©cup√©rer les informations d’un produit √† partir de son ID. Comme vous pouvez le voir, on fait une boucle ¬´¬†for¬†¬ª qui va parcourir l’ensemble des produits et si l’ID correspond √† ce qui sp√©cifi√© dans la requ√™te, on renvoie l’objet ¬´¬†product¬†¬ª avec son code HTTP 200 et si ce n’est pas le cas, on renvoie un message ¬´¬†Produit introuvable¬†¬ª accompagn√© d’un code d’erreur HTTP 404 qui correspond √† une ressource non trouv√©e.

    def get(self, id):
        for product in products:
            if (id == product["id"]):
                return product, 200
        return "Produit introuvable", 404

La fonction suivante va nous permettre de cr√©er un nouveau produit. La donn√©e utilis√©e dans la requ√™te √©tant structur√©e en JSON, cette fonction va utiliser le parseur de Flask pour extraire toutes les donn√©es du JSON et les ajouter √† notre tableau de produits : 

    def post(self, id):
        parser = reqparse.RequestParser()
        parser.add_argument("name")
        parser.add_argument("price")
        parser.add_argument("category")
        args = parser.parse_args()

        for product in products:
            if (id == product["id"]):
                return "Ce produit {} existe deja".format(id), 400

        product = {
            "id": id,
            "name": args["name"],
            "price": args["price"],
            "category": args["category"]
        }
        products.append(product)
        return product, 201

Une fois que le produit est cr√©√©, on retourne le code 201 qui veut dire que la cr√©ation s’est bien d√©roul√©e. Et si le produit existait d√©j√† avec cet ID, on renvoie le code 400 avec un message d’erreur.

La fonction put suivante est assez similaire puisqu’elle permet √† la fois de cr√©er un nouveau produit (si l’id n’est pas encore utilis√©) ou de mettre √† jour un produit existant.

    def put(self, id):
        parser = reqparse.RequestParser()
        parser.add_argument("name")
        parser.add_argument("price")
        parser.add_argument("category")
        args = parser.parse_args()

        for product in products:
            if (id == product["id"]):
                product["name"] = args["name"]
                product["price"] = args["price"]
                product["category"] = args["category"]
                return product, 200

        product = {
            "id": id,
            "name": args["name"],
            "price": args["price"],
            "category": args["category"]
        }
        products.append(product)
        return product, 201

Enfin, vous l’aurez compris, la fonction delete permettra de supprimer un enregistrement √† partir de son ID.

    def delete(self, id):
        global products
        products = [product for product in products if product["id"] != id]
        return "{} is deleted.".format(id), 200

Une fois ces fonctions d√©finies, il ne reste plus qu’√† sp√©cifier le format de l’URI qui sera utilis√© pour appeler l’API et lancer l’API (en mode debug pour d√©marrer). Le param√®tre <int:id> permet d’indiquer que dans le chemin du endpoint, on peut ajouter une variable accept√©e par l’API (ici l’ID du produit).

api.add_resource(Product, "/product/<int:id>")
app.run(debug=True)

Tester l’API avec Postman

Enfin, il ne reste plus qu’√† lancer le script python √† l’aide de la commande suivante : 

python3 productAPI.py

Le serveur web de Flask se lancera alors et vous verrez apparaitre une URL locale que vous pourrez appeler dans Postman pour ensuite tester votre API.

Voici le code complet du script pour information.
